awd_titl_txt: BIGDATA: IA: Collaborative Research:  Detecting Financial Market Manipulation: An Integrated Data- and Model-Driven Approach
awd_abstract_narration:
Financial stock market manipulators can profit illegally by misleading investors about market conditions. For example, in several recent incidents, manipulators successfully spoofed markets by inserting orders that deceived investors about supply or demand for the security. This kind of behavior has increased with the prevalence of algorithmic trading. It imposes substantial harm to the economy, by reducing the efficiency of capital allocation, and more seriously, threatening to compromise the integrity and stability of financial markets. Spoofing is difficult to detect because the underlying actions have legitimate purposes as well as nefarious ones. This project will apply innovative approaches to improve detection and deterrence of market manipulation.

The project will integrate data-driven methods, including calibration of detectors with normal background activity and extraction of manipulation signatures from enhanced time series, with model-based techniques for characterizing manipulation strategies based on strategic analysis of market microstructure. The key idea is to use simulation and optimization to generate successful manipulation strategies for trading models calibrated from available market data streams. These strategies will then be injected into the trading models, to produce enhanced data streams that include labeled manipulation activity. Having labeled activity enables the application of machine learning techniques to extract signatures of spoofing activity, which can be used to construct surveillance and audit algorithms. Methods produced in this project in conjunction with guidance on market design and regulation policy can contribute to reducing the threat from increasingly capable market manipulators.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
This project sought to understand how markets can be manipulated by human or automated traders, and how such manipulation can be detected or mitigated.  The simulation platform created for this purpose also proved useful in unanticipated ways.  During the project, we have:

  • Developed a novel, high-resolution open source discrete event simulation platform for financial markets and other applications, released at https://github.com/abides-sim/abides.  (c.f. article "ABIDES" in NSF-PAR)
  • Supported the validity of simulation for financial market research.  (c.f. article "Get Real" in NSF-PAR)
  • Introduced an efficient method to preserve user privacy during distributed machine learning. (c.f. article "Differentially private..." in NSF-PAR)
  • Developed a novel approach to fund constituent inference for financial market strategies. (c.f. article "Fund Asst Inference" in NSF-PAR)
  • Studied the effect of ETFs in transmitting volatility during a flash crash (c.f. article "Stability Effects" in NSF-PAR)
  • Developed a realistic financial market spoofing simulation and used it to collect a spoofing corpus and train a spoofing behavior detector.
  • Developed a novel approach for training an automated trading agent to seek profit while avoiding spoofing behavior.

We believe the project outcomes support the idea that high-resolution multi-agent simulation is an important approach to responsible machine learning in financial market research and beyond.

From our perspective, the key result is that unrestricted reinforcement learning can lead to unexpected and undesired outcomes, which can be mitigated through careful deliberation and a training process that specifically discourages adoption of behaviors that would lead to such outcomes.  We propose that financial institutions adopt such methods to reduce the risk of unintended adverse effects on the market systems in which they participate.


Last Modified: 12/30/2021
Modified by: David Byrd
